history.content:
Savio is decently powerful (470 nodes/11620 processor cores), however I am using it as an assistant to a researcher here at UC Berkeley. I do not know if you can use it on your own.

https://research-it.berkeley.edu/services/high-performance-computing

With that said, other students should add to this answer so that we can compile a list of resources/options for OP.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

There were also free GPUs to use that were stationed out of the CSUA. You need to sign up there and then they give you SSH access to the machines.

Savio is decently powerful (470 nodes/11620 processor cores), however I am using it as an assistant to a researcher here at UC Berkeley. I do not know if you can use it on your own.

https://research-it.berkeley.edu/services/high-performance-computing

With that said, other students should add to this answer so that we can compile a list of resources/options for OP.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

children.subject: +1. OCF got  funding for HPC and they are looking for people to use these services.

OCF is also worth contacting! They have a hell of a lot of cool stuff and they're super friendly.

Probably, XCF too if they're still around.

history.content: I hope everyone is having a good summer break. I was wondering if there are any high-performance computing resources (i.e. CPU/GPU clusters) that are available for use by EECS undergraduates. If these resources do exist, what are the time limitations and/or rates? Thanks.
history.subject: High Performance Computing Resources for Undergrads
